large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: I Am a Cat

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary (feature, family).
Begin Story Time by introducing the big book and asking, What are some features that cats have?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts; Ask and answer questions to seek help or information.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Join related sentences.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information; Talk and share.
Use information to describe; Use information to categorize; Use information to compare and contrast.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to classify animals as “cats” or “not cats,” even if they have some of the same features as cats.
Guide children to talk about the features of each animal they see.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What animals do you see in the book? What features do they have?
What animal can you pretend to be? What do you look like?
How can you sort those animals into different groups?
What animal could you draw? What features does it have?
What materials can you use to make your animal? How will you make its legs or other features?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word cat? Can you make that sound?
Can you use blocks to make an animal? What does the animal look like?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: I Am a Cat

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder flexible thinking and introduce vocabulary (confused, in common).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to I Am a Cat.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items; Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Use information to compare and contrast.
Explain that a shape remains the same shape even when its size or position changes.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children explore and talk about shapes and tell if they are part of the triangle family.
Encourage children to use flexible thinking to decide whether or not the shape is a triangle.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Which animal in your book has features just like Simon and the big cats?
Act like you are confused. Show what your face would look like.
Make two cats, one big and one small one. What can you tell about the big cat?
Think of a time when you felt confused. Can you write about it?
Draw a picture of your favorite big cat. What features would it have?
Write the letter C. Then add whiskers, perky ears, and a tail to make the letter look like a cat.
What materials would you use to build a tall tree for an animal that has sharp claws and likes to climb?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: I Am a Cat

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Listen and Remember and introduce vocabulary (mane, tough).
Begin Story Time by revisiting I Am a Cat and asking the guiding question, How are some cats different from others?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Join related sentences.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information; Talk and share; Make connections between situations.
Use information to compare and contrast.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children recall details and vocabulary from the story that will help them talk about different cats.
Talk about what makes each cat special and extend conversational turn-taking.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are the animals in your book the same? How are they different?
How would an animal with four legs walk? How would an animal with two legs jump? Show me.
How could you show which animal has the longest tail?
Why might some cats have different-colored fur? Can you write about it?
Draw and color cats with different-colored fur.
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the words teeth and tails?
Cheetah says cats are tall. What materials can you use to build a tall cat?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. I Am a Cat by Galia Bernstein. Copyright © 2017 Galia Bernstein. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Abrams Books for Young Readers, an imprint of ABRAMS.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Aleksey Sagitov/Shutterstock.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Fantastic Feet

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about animals and to introduce vocabulary words (foot, feet).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Fantastic Feet and I Am a Cat.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information; Talk and share; Make connections between situations.
Use information to describe.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Show children pictures of different animal feet, provide clues about the feet, and challenge children to identify each animal.
Invite children to pose their own questions about animal feet.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do you think the animal in that book is good at doing? Why do you think that?
Show how you would walk if you had duck feet. How would you walk if you had horse feet?
Can you name the fastest cat we learned about this week? What do you know about this cat?
Can you tell a story about an animal from Fantastic Feet?
Can you use clay to make an animal from Fantastic Feet?
Which letter makes the beginning sound you hear in the words Fantastic and Feet? Can you make that sound?
Can you imagine the biggest foot in the world? How many toes would it have?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. I Am a Cat by Galia Bernstein. Copyright © 2017 Galia Bernstein. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Abrams Books for Young Readers, an imprint of ABRAMS.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Aleksey Sagitov/Shutterstock.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: I Am a Cat

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to invite children to talk about animal features and to introduce vocabulary (tremble, leap).
Start Story Time by revisiting the big book and asking, If you were a cat, what feature would you most want to have?
Read and retell interactively.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Talk and share; Make connections between situations.
Use information to compare and contrast; Share and repeat the details in a text.
Write for different purposes.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: “If you had cat features, how would you use them?”
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you were to write your own book about animal features, what would you put in it?
Pretend to be a cat no one has seen before. What will your most important feature be?
Imagine you are a puma and leap as far as you can. How can you measure how far you jumped?
Can you make up a story about a cat that can run really fast?
Will you draw your favorite animal? What colors will you use?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word tremble?
Can you create a tree for a panther to sleep in? What materials will you use?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Combine sentences that give lots of detail, stick to the topic, and clearly communicate intended meaning.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Use a variety of words to label and describe people, places, and things.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items; Show flexible thinking and behavior.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Slide, flip, and turn shapes to show that they remain the same.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Combine sentences that give lots of detail and clearly communicate intended meaning.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information; Talk and share; Make connections between situations.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Observe, describe, and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information; Talk and share; Make connections between situations.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Use a variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Talk and share; Make connections between situations.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
